clueRoots: Extensive white mycelial fans visible under bark at root collar when bark peeled, firm texture, spreading pattern
clueButt: Black rhizomorphs (bootlaces) visible in soil radiating from base, 2-4mm diameter, tough and string-like
clueLowerStem: No visible external symptoms on bark surface
clueFoliage: Progressive crown thinning starting in upper crown, 45% density, leaves smaller than normal, premature autumn color
whyThisFungus: The combination of white mycelial fans under bark PLUS black rhizomorphs in soil is DIAGNOSTIC for Armillaria. No other fungus produces bootlace-like rhizomorphs. Crown thinning without lower stem symptoms indicates root/vascular compromise from below. Often no fruiting bodies visible when symptoms appear.
keyDifferentiators: GANODERMA: Has woody brackets at base, NO rhizomorphs, brown spore deposits. INONOTUS DRYADEUS: Amber droplets on brackets, NO rhizomorphs. MERIPILUS: Large rosette fruiting bodies with brown bruising, NO rhizomorphs. UNIQUE TO ARMILLARIA: Rhizomorphs are unique (only this genus), white mycelial fans under bark, mushroomy smell when bark peeled, often no visible fruiting when tree symptomatic.
clinicalNotes: Smell: Strong mushroomy odor under bark when peeled. Progression: Can kill trees in 2-5 years or persist for decades depending on host vigor. Host range: Very wide (most broadleaves and conifers susceptible). Spread: Root-to-root contact underground. Risk level: HIGH - aggressive pathogen, can spread through tree populations.
examTip: If you see "rhizomorphs" or "bootlaces" in exam question ? ALWAYS Armillaria (no other fungus has these). If "mycelial fans under bark at collar" ? likely Armillaria, definitive if rhizomorphs also present. Remember double-L in Armillaria and double-L in mellea.

clueRoots: Root flare shows soft fibrous white rot when probed, spongy texture, structural roots affected in excavation
clueButt: Large hoof-shaped perennial brackets present, concentrically zoned brown upper surface, white margin when actively growing, hard and woody texture
clueLowerStem: White pore surface on underside of brackets, brown spore deposits visible on ground or lower bark below brackets
clueFoliage: Crown density 70-80%, appears relatively healthy despite root decay
whyThisFungus: Brown spore deposits on ground beneath brackets are diagnostic for Ganoderma genus. Hoof-shaped woody brackets with zoned brown surface distinguish G. australe. Root decay causes windthrow risk while crown appears deceptively healthy (roots fail before vascular function compromised). White fibrous rot in roots typical.
keyDifferentiators: GANODERMA APPLANATUM: Flat shelf-like brackets (not hoof-shaped), thinner, grey-brown color. GANODERMA RESINACEUM: Resinous coating on bracket surface. MERIPILUS: Rosette form at base, brown bruising diagnostic. INONOTUS DRYADEUS: Amber droplets, rough bracket surface. UNIQUE TO G. AUSTRALE: Hoof-shaped form, zoned brown surface, hard woody texture, heavy spore deposits, white pore surface.
clinicalNotes: Location: Root collar and root flare, rarely higher on stem. Decay type: White rot of roots (soft, fibrous, stringy). Failure mode: Windthrow most common (roots fail). Crown condition: Often healthy appearance until failure (misleading). Spores: Prolific brown spore production creates deposits. Growth: Perennial brackets add new layer each year.
examTip: Look for HOOF-SHAPED bracket = G. australe. If FLAT shelf = G. applanatum. Heavy brown spore deposits = Ganoderma genus (multiple species possible). Remember: Ganoderma has two N's, australe has no double letters. "Australe" means "southern" - remember "Australia" connection.

clueRoots: Root plate excavation shows white rot in structural roots, stringy fibrous texture
clueButt: Large flat shelf-like brackets at base, grey-brown upper surface (not zoned), overlapping tiers possible, very hard woody texture
clueLowerStem: Brackets can extend up lower stem, flat shelf form continues, brown spore deposits accumulate on lower bark
clueFoliage: Crown 75% density, foliage appears healthy despite root compromise
whyThisFungus: Flat shelf-like brackets distinguish G. applanatum from hoof-shaped G. australe. Grey-brown (not concentrically zoned brown) upper surface diagnostic. White pore surface browns when scratched (artist's bracket name origin). Massive brown spore production creates heavy deposits. Root rot while crown healthy = typical Ganoderma pattern.
keyDifferentiators: GANODERMA AUSTRALE: Hoof-shaped (not flat), zoned brown surface. GANODERMA RESINACEUM: Resinous coating. FOMES FOMENTARIUS: Grey hoof-shaped, on beech, higher on stem. POLYPORUS SQUAMOSUS: Scaly cap, cream pores, distinct stalk. UNIQUE TO G. APPLANATUM: Flat shelf form, grey-brown color (not zoned), white pore surface browns when scratched, can draw on pore surface (artist's use).
clinicalNotes: Location: Base and lower stem, can extend higher than G. australe. Size: Very large brackets possible (30-50cm diameter). Spores: Prolific spore production, brown deposits diagnostic. Pore surface: White, browns permanently when scratched (artwork surface). Multiple tiers: Often overlapping shelf brackets. Annual growth: Perennial, new pore layer each year.
examTip: FLAT shelf = G. applanatum. HOOF-shaped = G. australe. Scratch test: If white pore surface browns when scratched = G. applanatum (diagnostic test). Remember spelling: applanatum has double-P, double-N. Think "apple-anus" for weird memory trick.

clueRoots: Root collar shows extensive decay, soft and crumbly when probed, roots compromised in excavation
clueButt: Brackets at root collar, rough surface texture, amber droplets visible (weeping appearance), bracket underside pores rust-brown
clueLowerStem: No brackets typically present on lower stem
clueFoliage: Crown density 80%, appears healthy despite severe root decay
whyThisFungus: Amber droplets on bracket surface are DIAGNOSTIC - no other common fungus has this weeping appearance. Root collar location specific. Rust-brown pore surface distinctive. Causes severe root decay while crown remains deceptively healthy. Oak specialist (occasionally other broadleaves).
keyDifferentiators: GANODERMA: Hoof or shelf form, NO amber droplets, white pores, brown spores. MERIPILUS: Rosette form, brown bruising, NO droplets. POLYPORUS SQUAMOSUS: Scaly cap, cream pores, stalk present, NO droplets. UNIQUE TO INONOTUS DRYADEUS: Amber droplets (unique weeping), root collar location, rough irregular bracket, rust-brown pores, oak association.
clinicalNotes: Host: Primarily oak (Quercus), occasionally sweet chestnut. Location: Root collar specifically (not higher stem). Droplets: Amber liquid exudate on young brackets (may dry in older brackets). Decay: White rot of roots, severe anchorage loss. Failure: Windthrow risk high. Smell: No distinctive odor. Progression: Slow, tree may survive years with extensive decay.
examTip: If you see "amber droplets" or "weeping" on brackets ? ALWAYS Inonotus dryadeus (unique feature). "Dryadeus" refers to dryads (oak tree spirits) - oak association. Remember: Inonotus has one-N, dryadeus has Y not I in middle. Droplets = diagnostic clincher.

clueRoots: Root plate shows white rot decay, roots soft and crumbly, multiple structural roots affected in excavation
clueButt: Large rosette of overlapping brackets at base, total diameter can exceed 1 meter, individual brackets fan-shaped
clueLowerStem: Brackets occasionally extend onto lower stem base
clueFoliage: Crown 70% density, some thinning evident, tree shows stress symptoms
whyThisFungus: Rosette form with overlapping fan-shaped brackets is diagnostic. Brown/black bruising when bracket touched (fresh brackets) - unique identifier. Very large overall size (can exceed 1m diameter rosette). Annual fruiting (not perennial like Ganoderma). Causes severe root decay and windthrow risk.
keyDifferentiators: GANODERMA: Hoof or shelf form (not rosette), hard woody texture, perennial, NO bruising. INONOTUS DRYADEUS: Smaller brackets, amber droplets, NO bruising. POLYPORUS SQUAMOSUS: Individual stalked brackets, scaly cap, NO bruising, cream pores. UNIQUE TO MERIPILUS: Rosette form, brown/black bruising when touched (diagnostic), very large size, annual brackets (soft texture), cream-brown pore surface.
clinicalNotes: Fruiting: Annual (appears late summer/autumn, degrades over winter). Size: Very large rosettes, impressive when fully developed. Bruising: Fresh brackets bruise brown/black when handled (diagnostic test). Decay: White rot of roots and root collar. Failure mode: Windthrow. Smell: No strong odor. Previous fruiting: Check for old degraded brackets from previous years (fibrous remains).
examTip: If description says "bruises brown/black when touched" ? ALWAYS Meripilus (unique feature among common fungi). "Giganteus" = giant size. Rosette form diagnostic. Remember: Meripilus has one-R, giganteus has one-G. Bruising test = quick ID in field.

clueRoots: No visible root symptoms typically
clueButt: Grey powdery patches on bark at base, progressing to black crusty stromata, bark loose and easily removed, tissue beneath dark and brittle
clueLowerStem: Black crusty stromata extend up lower stem, can cover 180-270° of circumference, bark falls away revealing black tissue
clueUpperStem: Extension of stromata may reach 2-3m height in advanced cases
clueFoliage: Crown thinning and dieback in advanced stages, leaves smaller, premature yellowing
whyThisFungus: Grey to black stromata progression diagnostic (grey powdery stage progresses to black crusty hard stage). Causes uniquely BRITTLE decay (ceramic-like fracture). Most dangerous decay fungus due to sudden failure with minimal warning. Affects stem not roots. Often called "brittle cinder" or "Ustulina deusta" (older name).
keyDifferentiators: ARMILLARIA: White fans + rhizomorphs, NO stromata, affects roots. GANODERMA: Brackets present, affects roots, NOT brittle. BJERKANDERA: Small thin brackets on deadwood, NOT brittle, saprophytic. UNIQUE TO KRETZSCHMARIA: Grey-to-black stromata progression, causes BRITTLE decay (unique), sudden failure mode, stem-based (not root), most dangerous common fungus, minimal external symptoms until late.
clinicalNotes: Progression: Grey powdery ? black crusty stromata. Decay type: Soft rot causing BRITTLE ceramic-like fracture. Failure mode: Sudden catastrophic snap (no warning). Location: Lower stem primarily (not roots). Danger level: HIGHEST - unpredictable sudden failure. Warning: Healthy crown appearance until very late stage (misleading). Speed: Relatively fast progression once established. Old name: Ustulina deusta (synonym still used).
examTip: If description includes "brittle" or "ceramic fracture" ? ALWAYS Kretzschmaria (unique decay type). Grey-to-black progression diagnostic. Most dangerous common fungus = emergency removal usually required. Remember: Kretzschmaria has unusual spelling (K-r-e-t-z), "deusta" means "burnt" (black appearance). Also called Ustulina deusta (old name) - know both.

clueRoots: No visible root symptoms
clueButt: Brackets occasionally present at base but more typically higher on stem
clueLowerStem: Perennial hoof-shaped brackets, grey upper surface with concentric grooves, hard woody texture, multiple brackets at various heights
clueUpperStem: Brackets common on upper stem, hoof form continues
clueBranches: Brackets may appear on larger branch unions
clueFoliage: Crown thinning progressive, decay affects scaffold branches at attachment points
whyThisFungus: Grey hoof-shaped perennial brackets on STEM (not base) diagnostic. Concentric grooves on grey surface. Beech specialist primarily. White rot of heartwood. Brackets hard and woody (historically used as tinder - name origin). Distinguished from Ganoderma by grey color, beech host, stem location (not root collar).
keyDifferentiators: GANODERMA AUSTRALE: Brown zoned surface (not grey), base location (not stem), heavy spore deposits. PHELLINUS: Grey-black (not grey), different texture, willow host. POLYPORUS: Scaly surface, stalked, cream pores. UNIQUE TO FOMES: Grey color, hoof form, concentric grooves, beech association, STEM location (not base), hard texture, slow growing perennial, no spore deposits visible.
clinicalNotes: Host: Beech primarily (occasionally birch, other broadleaves). Location: Main stem at various heights (NOT typically at base like Ganoderma). Decay: White rot of heartwood (slow progression). Brackets: Perennial, add layer annually, very hard. Historical use: Used as tinder for fire-starting (punk wood). Size: Medium (10-20cm typical). Color: Distinctive grey (not brown like Ganoderma).
examTip: GREY hoof on BEECH STEM = Fomes fomentarius. BROWN hoof at BASE = Ganoderma. Location key to separation. Remember: "Fomes" = tinder (fire starting), "fomentarius" = same root. Grey color + beech host = diagnostic combination. One-M in Fomes.

clueRoots: No visible root symptoms
clueButt: No brackets typically at base
clueLowerStem: Brackets appear on main stem, rough hairy upper surface, rust-brown color, soft velvety texture when young, becoming harder with age
clueUpperStem: Brackets common on upper stem at old branch stubs or wounds, irregular bracket shape
clueBranches: Brackets at branch attachment points on larger scaffold branches
clueFoliage: Crown shows dieback in areas above bracket locations, dead branches evident, thinning in affected sectors
whyThisFungus: Rough hairy/shaggy bracket surface diagnostic (hispid = hairy). Rust-brown color. Appears at branch stubs and wounds on stem/branches (not at base). Causes localized decay at attachment points. Ash specialist primarily. Annual brackets (not perennial). Soft when fresh, hardens with age.
keyDifferentiators: FOMES: Grey (not rust-brown), smooth (not hairy), perennial, beech host, hoof-shaped. POLYPORUS SQUAMOSUS: Scaly (not hairy), cream pores, stalked, larger. PHELLINUS: Grey-black, not hairy surface. UNIQUE TO INONOTUS HISPIDUS: Hairy/shaggy surface (hispidus = hairy), rust-brown color, ash association, branch/wound locations, annual brackets, causes branch dieback above bracket.
clinicalNotes: Host: Ash primarily (Fraxinus), occasionally apple, walnut, London plane. Location: Stem and branches at old wounds or pruning cuts. Texture: Rough hairy surface (diagnostic), soft when young. Color: Rust-brown to brown. Form: Irregular bracket, no hoof shape. Decay: Brown rot localized around bracket. Failure: Branch drop at bracket location. Annual: Degrades over winter (not perennial).
examTip: Hairy or "shaggy" brackets on ASH ? Inonotus hispidus. "Hispidus" literally means hairy/bristly. Ash association key. Remember: Inonotus (one-N), hispidus (one-S at start, one-D). Hairy texture = feel for this in field inspection.

clueRoots: Root collar shows white rot decay in advanced cases
clueButt: Pale buff to cream colored perennial brackets at base, concentrically grooved surface, relatively hard texture
clueLowerStem: Brackets occasionally extend to lower stem
clueFoliage: Crown thinning and dieback progressive over several years
whyThisFungus: Pale buff/cream perennial brackets diagnostic. Ash specialist. White rot of roots and butt. Brackets show concentric growth rings (perennial). Relatively inconspicuous compared to large Ganoderma brackets. Associated with veteran ash trees. Less aggressive than Armillaria but still serious.
keyDifferentiators: GANODERMA: Brown or grey-brown (not pale buff), larger brackets, not ash-specific. POLYPORUS SQUAMOSUS: Scaly cap, cream pores, stalked, annual. TRAMETES: Thin brackets, different texture. UNIQUE TO PERENNIPORIA: Pale buff/cream color, ash association (fraxinea = of ash), perennial growth, white rot of roots, veteran tree association, relatively small inconspicuous brackets.
clinicalNotes: Host: Ash (Fraxinus) primarily, occasionally other hosts. Location: Base and root collar primarily. Color: Pale buff to cream (distinctive pale color). Brackets: Perennial, concentrically grooved. Size: Smaller than Ganoderma (5-15cm typical). Decay: White rot of roots and butt. Association: Often on veteran/ancient ash trees. Progression: Slower than Armillaria but still serious.
examTip: Pale buff brackets on ASH = likely Perenniporia fraxinea. "Fraxinea" directly means "of ash" (Fraxinus). Less well-known than Ganoderma but important on veteran ash. Remember: Perenniporia (double-N, double-R), fraxinea (one-X). Pale color + ash host = key combination.

clueRoots: No visible root symptoms
clueButt: Annual brackets may appear at base but more commonly higher
clueLowerStem: Bright yellow to orange brackets, soft texture when fresh, bracket edges bright yellow, overlapping shelf form
clueUpperStem: Brackets common on main stem, vibrant color obvious, multiple tiers possible
clueBranches: Large brackets can appear at major branch unions
clueFoliage: Crown shows dieback and dead branches in areas above brackets, tree vigor declining
whyThisFungus: Bright yellow to orange color is immediately diagnostic - no other common fungus this color. Soft texture when fresh. Causes brown rot with delamination pattern (separates wood along growth rings). Annual brackets (appear summer, degrade over winter). Edible when young (chicken flavor - name origin). Multiple overlapping shelves.
keyDifferentiators: FOMES: Grey (not yellow), hoof form. GANODERMA: Brown (not yellow), root location. POLYPORUS: Scaly cap, cream pores, stalked. INONOTUS HISPIDUS: Rust-brown (not bright yellow). UNIQUE TO LAETIPORUS: Bright yellow/orange color (unmistakable), soft texture, causes brown rot with delamination, edible when young, sulphur yellow color gives species name.
clinicalNotes: Color: Bright yellow to orange (vibrant, diagnostic). Texture: Soft and moist when fresh (hardens and fades with age). Decay: Brown rot causing delamination (wood separates in sheets). Location: Stem and branches, occasionally base. Edibility: Edible when young (chicken flavor), popular foraged mushroom. Smell: No strong odor. Size: Large brackets (20-40cm), multiple tiers. Name: "Sulphureus" = sulphur yellow color.
examTip: If exam shows BRIGHT YELLOW brackets ? ALWAYS Laetiporus sulphureus (unique color). No other common fungus this vibrant. "Chicken of the woods" common name may appear. Remember: Laetiporus (one-T), sulphureus (ph-sound spelled as "ph" or just "f" - check which spelling standard). Sulphur = yellow (color matches name).

clueRoots: No visible root symptoms
clueButt: Annual brackets at base common, deep red-brown color, soft texture, bleeds red juice when cut
clueLowerStem: Brackets on lower stem particularly in cavities, bleeding appearance when fresh
clueFoliage: Crown healthy in early stages, shows stress in advanced decay
whyThisFungus: Deep red-brown brackets bleeding red juice diagnostic (beefsteak appearance). Soft texture. Causes slow brown cubical rot (different from white rots). Sweet chestnut and oak specialist. Annual brackets (summer/autumn). Cavity colonization common. Distinctive appearance unlike other fungi.
keyDifferentiators: GANODERMA: Brown but hard woody, no bleeding, white rot. LAETIPORUS: Yellow/orange (not red-brown), no bleeding. INONOTUS: Rust-brown, no bleeding. UNIQUE TO FISTULINA: Bleeds red juice when cut (beefsteak appearance), soft texture, brown cubical rot, sweet chestnut/oak specialist, annual brackets, cavity colonization, relatively slow decay.
clinicalNotes: Color: Deep red-brown (raw meat appearance). Texture: Soft, tongue-like (fleshy). Bleeding: Red juice when cut or bruised (diagnostic). Decay: Brown cubical rot (slow progression). Host: Sweet chestnut primarily, oak commonly, rarely other broadleaves. Location: Base and stem, particularly in cavities. Edibility: Edible (sour taste). Season: Summer to autumn. Progression: Slow (tree may survive decades).
examTip: If "bleeding red juice" or "beefsteak" mentioned ? ALWAYS Fistulina hepatica (unique feature). "Hepatica" = liver-like (appearance/texture). Sweet chestnut association strong. Remember: Fistulina (one-S), hepatica (one-T). Bleeding diagnostic - test in field by cutting small piece.

clueRoots: No visible root symptoms
clueButt: Brackets occasionally at base
clueLowerStem: Perennial hoof-shaped brackets on stem, grey-black upper surface, very hard texture, rusty-brown lower surface when broken
clueUpperStem: Multiple brackets at various stem heights, hard woody texture continues
clueBranches: Brackets can appear on larger branches
clueFoliage: Crown thinning progressive, willow shows characteristic stress response with epicormic growth
whyThisFungus: Grey-black hoof-shaped brackets diagnostic. Very hard (hardest common bracket - "igniarius" = fire-resistant historically). Willow specialist primarily. White rot of heartwood. Perennial brackets (slow growing, add layers annually). Distinguished from Fomes by darker color, willow host, harder texture.
keyDifferentiators: FOMES: Lighter grey (not grey-black), beech host (not willow), similar form. GANODERMA: Brown color, base location, spore deposits. INONOTUS: Rust-brown, hairy, ash host. UNIQUE TO PHELLINUS IGNIARIUS: Grey-black color, extremely hard texture (hardest common bracket), willow specialist, white rot, very slow growing perennial, rusty-brown context when broken.
clinicalNotes: Host: Willow (Salix) primarily, poplar occasionally. Location: Main stem at various heights. Color: Grey-black upper surface, rusty-brown when broken internally. Texture: Extremely hard woody (historically used in fire-starting due to hardness/slow burning). Brackets: Perennial, very slow growing. Decay: White rot of heartwood (slow). Size: Medium (10-25cm). Shape: Hoof-shaped.
examTip: GREY-BLACK hoof on WILLOW stem = Phellinus igniarius. Extremely hard texture (test by trying to break piece off - very difficult). "Igniarius" = relating to fire (historical use). Remember: Phellinus (double-L), igniarius (one-G). Willow specialist = key to ID.

clueRoots: No visible root symptoms
clueButt: Brackets can appear at base on dead/dying birch
clueLowerStem: Annual brackets on stem, round to kidney-shaped, pale grey-brown upper surface smooth, white pore surface underneath
clueUpperStem: Multiple brackets up entire stem length on dead or dying birch, bracket underside pure white
clueBranches: Brackets on branches of dead birch
clueFoliage: Crown extensively dead or dying (70-90% deadwood), bark peeling, tree in terminal decline
whyThisFungus: Birch specialist (betulinus = of birch). Round/kidney-shaped brackets. Pale grey-brown smooth upper surface. White pore surface underneath. Saprophytic colonization of dead/dying birch. Tree extensively dead when brackets appear. Not pathogenic - colonizes after tree already dying from other causes.
keyDifferentiators: FOMES: Grey but hoof-shaped (not round), perennial, beech host. TRAMETES: Thinner, different hosts. GANODERMA: Brown, base location, different shape. UNIQUE TO PIPTOPORUS: Birch specialist (very specific), round/kidney shape, smooth pale surface, white pores, saprophytic (not pathogenic), appears on dead/dying trees only, annual brackets.
clinicalNotes: Host: Birch (Betula) exclusively. Ecology: Saprophytic (colonizes dead/dying birch, not cause of death). Form: Round to kidney-shaped. Color: Pale grey-brown smooth upper, white pore lower. Size: Medium (10-20cm). Season: Annual (appears late summer/autumn). Tree condition: Always on dead/dying birch (extensive deadwood present). Historical: Used medicinally (razor strop fungus).
examTip: If BIRCH with ROUND brackets ? Piptoporus betulinus. Very host-specific. NOT pathogenic - appears after tree dying from other causes (Armillaria, age, stress). "Betulinus" = of birch (Betula). Remember: Piptoporus (one-P at start, one-T), betulinus (one-T). White pores diagnostic.

clueRoots: No visible root symptoms
clueButt: Brackets can appear at base
clueLowerStem: Perennial hoof-shaped brackets, distinctive red-brown band at margin, grey-black old surface, resinous appearance
clueUpperStem: Brackets common on main stem of conifers, red margin diagnostic feature continues
clueBranches: Brackets on dead branches and stubs
clueFoliage: Crown shows deadwood in lower sections, epicormic growth below live crown on pines
whyThisFungus: Red-brown margin/band on bracket edge diagnostic. Perennial brackets on conifers (pine, spruce, fir). Grey-black older surface with red-brown actively growing margin. Resinous appearance. Causes brown cubical rot. Distinguished from other conifer brackets by red margin.
keyDifferentiators: GANODERMA RESINACEUM: Brown, resinous, but no red margin, different host range. FOMES: Grey throughout (no red margin), beech host. PHELLINUS: Grey-black throughout (no red margin), willow host. UNIQUE TO FOMITOPSIS: Red-brown margin band (diagnostic), conifer specialist, brown cubical rot, resinous appearance, grey-black old surface contrasts with red margin.
clinicalNotes: Host: Conifers (pine, spruce, fir, larch), occasionally broadleaves. Location: Stem, branches, stumps. Color: Red-brown margin (actively growing edge), grey-black old surface. Texture: Hard woody, resinous. Decay: Brown cubical rot. Brackets: Perennial, hoof-shaped. Size: Medium to large (10-30cm). "Pinicola" = pine-dweller (conifer association).
examTip: RED MARGIN on bracket = Fomitopsis pinicola (diagnostic feature). On CONIFERS primarily. "Pinicola" = living on pine (conifer host). Remember: Fomitopsis (one-M, one-T), pinicola (one-N, one-C). Red-belted common name describes red margin. Brown cubical rot = brown rot (vs white rot).

clueRoots: No visible root symptoms
clueButt: Small thin brackets on dead branch stubs in lower crown, pale grey upper surface, smoky-grey pore surface underneath
clueLowerStem: Small brackets on dead stub ends on main stem, thin leathery texture
clueUpperStem: Small brackets on dead stubs at pruning cuts higher up
clueBranches: Numerous small brackets on dead branch stubs throughout crown, tree otherwise healthy
clueFoliage: Crown overall healthy (70-80% density), deadwood normal for species/age, no abnormal dieback
whyThisFungus: Small thin leathery brackets on DEAD WOOD only. Smoky-grey pore surface diagnostic (adusta = scorched/smoky). Saprophytic - colonizes dead tissue only, NOT pathogenic. Normal in trees with natural deadwood. Distinguished from pathogens by ONLY appearing on confirmed dead stubs, never on living wood.
keyDifferentiators: GANODERMA: Large woody brackets at base, pathogenic. FOMES: Larger hoof-shaped, on living wood. POLYPORUS: Larger, stalked, scaly. ARMILLARIA: Fans under bark, pathogenic, rhizomorphs. UNIQUE TO BJERKANDERA: Small thin brackets, EXCLUSIVELY on dead wood (never living), smoky-grey pores diagnostic, saprophytic (not pathogenic), normal presence in healthy trees.
clinicalNotes: Ecology: Strictly saprophytic (dead wood only). Location: Dead branch stubs, pruning cuts, dead twigs. Color: Pale grey upper, smoky-grey pore surface. Size: Small (2-5cm typical). Texture: Thin, leathery. Pathogenicity: NONE - not a threat to tree health. Significance: Indicates deadwood present (normal in maturing trees), NOT disease. "Adusta" = scorched (smoky grey color reference).
examTip: If brackets ONLY on dead stubs/branches with no living wood invasion ? Bjerkandera adusta (saprophyte). If on living wood ? different fungus (pathogen). Smoky-grey pores diagnostic. Client education important: NOT a disease, normal decomposition. Remember: Bjerkandera (unusual spelling, one-R), adusta (one-D). Saprophyte vs pathogen critical distinction.

clueRoots: Root flare shows white rot decay when probed
clueButt: Large brackets at base, brown upper surface with distinctive resinous lacquered coating giving shiny appearance, hard woody texture
clueLowerStem: Brackets occasionally on lower stem, resinous coating continues
clueFoliage: Crown 75% density, appears healthy despite root decay
whyThisFungus: Resinous lacquered coating on bracket surface diagnostic. Brown color. Hard woody perennial brackets. Root and butt rot. Similar to G. australe but distinguished by resinous coating. Oak and beech primarily. White rot of roots causes windthrow risk while crown deceptively healthy.
keyDifferentiators: GANODERMA AUSTRALE: No resinous coating (matte surface), hoof-shaped. GANODERMA APPLANATUM: Flat shelf (not resinous coating), grey-brown. FOMITOPSIS: Red margin, conifer host, brown rot. UNIQUE TO G. RESINACEUM: Resinous lacquered coating (shiny appearance diagnostic), brown color, perennial, white rot, oak/beech association, similar growth pattern to other Ganoderma but resinous surface separates it.
clinicalNotes: Location: Base and root collar primarily. Coating: Resinous lacquer giving shiny appearance (diagnostic vs other Ganoderma). Host: Oak and beech primarily. Decay: White rot of roots. Brackets: Perennial, hard woody. Failure: Windthrow. Size: Large (15-40cm). Crown: Healthy appearance until failure. "Resinaceum" = resinous (coating gives name). Less common than G. australe/applanatum but distinctive when present.
examTip: SHINY RESINOUS coating on Ganoderma bracket = G. resinaceum (vs matte surface of G. australe). Feel surface - should feel lacquered/varnished. Remember: resinaceum (one-S, one-C). "Resinous" in name describes diagnostic coating. Oak/beech primarily. All Ganoderma cause root rot, separation by bracket characteristics.

clueRoots: No visible root symptoms
clueButt: Large brackets at base, distinctive scaly cap surface (brown scales on cream background), cream to pale yellow pore surface underneath, bracket on distinct stalk/stem
clueLowerStem: Brackets on lower stem particularly at old wounds or cavities, scaly pattern continues
clueUpperStem: Brackets on upper stem at branch stubs or wounds
clueBranches: Large brackets can appear at major branch unions
clueFoliage: Crown shows dieback in sections above bracket locations, localized decline
whyThisFungus: Large cream-colored brackets with BROWN SCALES on cap surface diagnostic (squamosus = scaly). Distinctive short lateral stalk. Cream to yellow pores underneath. Annual brackets (summer). Causes white rot at wounds/branch stubs. Edible when very young. Strong mealy smell. Distinguished from other brackets by scaly pattern + stalk + cream pores.
keyDifferentiators: FOMES: Grey hoof, no scales, no stalk, perennial. GANODERMA: Brown or grey, no scales, no stalk. LAETIPORUS: Yellow/orange, no scales, no stalk. UNIQUE TO POLYPORUS SQUAMOSUS: Scaly cap (brown scales on cream - diagnostic), distinct lateral stalk, cream/yellow pores, large size, mealy smell, annual brackets, causes decay at wounds not base/roots.
clinicalNotes: Cap: Large (20-60cm possible), scaly surface (brown scales on cream background). Stalk: Distinctive short lateral stalk (not directly attached to wood). Pores: Cream to pale yellow (large angular pores). Smell: Strong mealy/watermelon rind smell. Season: Annual (late spring/early summer). Decay: White rot at wounds. Edibility: Young brackets edible (tough when mature). "Squamosus" = scaly. "Dryad's saddle" = large saddle-like form.
examTip: SCALY CAP + SHORT STALK = Polyporus squamosus (only common bracket with this combination). Large size, cream color, mealy smell all support ID. Remember: Polyporus (one-Y), squamosus (one-M). Scaly pattern unmistakable in field. Annual = appears late spring, grows fast, degrades by autumn.

clueRoots: No visible root symptoms
clueButt: Large perennial brackets at base, grey-brown to rusty-brown rough upper surface, very hard texture, bracket edge rusty-orange when actively growing
clueLowerStem: Brackets occasionally extend to lower stem base
clueFoliage: Crown shows thinning and dieback in advanced stages
whyThisFungus: Large rough perennial brackets at base. Grey-brown to rusty-brown color. Very hard texture. Rusty-orange active growing edge. Oak specialist. White rot of heartwood at base and lower stem. Distinguished from Ganoderma by rough texture, rusty tones, extremely hard brackets. Less common than Ganoderma but significant on mature oaks.
keyDifferentiators: GANODERMA: Smooth surface (not rough), brown or grey-brown, zoned or flat form. PHELLINUS IGNIARIUS: Grey-black, willow host (not oak), stem location. INONOTUS: Hairy surface, rust-brown, ash host, annual. UNIQUE TO PHELLINUS ROBUSTUS: Rough texture, rusty-orange growing edge, oak specialist, extremely hard, perennial, white rot of base/lower stem, robust size gives species name.
clinicalNotes: Host: Oak (Quercus) primarily, occasionally other broadleaves. Location: Base and lower stem. Texture: Very hard (extremely dense wood), rough surface. Color: Grey-brown to rusty-brown, rusty-orange active edge. Size: Large (can exceed 30cm), robust (gives name). Decay: White rot of heartwood. Brackets: Perennial, slow growing. "Robustus" = robust/strong (refers to size and hard texture).
examTip: ROUGH RUSTY brackets on OAK base = likely Phellinus robustus. Very hard texture (similar to P. igniarius hardness). Rusty-orange growing edge diagnostic. Remember: Phellinus (double-L), robustus (one-B). Less common than Ganoderma on oak but distinctive. Rough texture + rusty tones + oak host = combination for ID.

clueRoots: White mycelial mat visible under bark at root collar of conifers when lifted, resinous smell, resin soaking into surrounding soil
clueButt: Irregular shelf-like fruiting body at base of conifer, pale cream/white pore surface on underside, brown-grey irregular upper surface, hard and woody
clueLowerStem: White resinous decay visible in basal wood when probed, no obvious external symptoms on bark surface
clueFoliage: Crown thinning and yellowing in Scots pine, needle drop, resin flow on stem — tree declining from below while upper crown still appears partially active
whyThisFungus: The white pore surface and cream-white irregular bracket at the BASE OF CONIFERS is the key combination. No rhizomorphs (unlike Armillaria). No amber droplets. Causes devastating butt and root rot in conifer plantations — most economically destructive forest pathogen in Europe. Resinous smell and resin-soaked soil are supporting clues.
keyDifferentiators: ARMILLARIA: Rhizomorphs present, white mycelial fans, affects broadleaves and conifers. PHAEOLUS: Yellow-green active margin, annual, spongy texture. SPARASSIS: Cauliflower form, no shelf bracket. UNIQUE TO HETEROBASIDION: White/cream irregular pore surface at conifer base, no rhizomorphs, resin-soaking diagnostic, devastating plantation pathogen, spread via root contact and airborne spores to fresh stumps.
clinicalNotes: Host: Conifers primarily (Scots pine, Norway spruce, Douglas fir, larch). Spread: Root-to-root contact AND airborne spores colonising fresh cut stumps — stump treatment mandatory after felling in infected stands. Decay: White rot of butt and roots. Risk: Catastrophic in plantations — can render entire stands unstable. Detection: Often no external symptoms until advanced decay. Legal: Stump treatment legally required in some forestry contexts.
examTip: WHITE irregular bracket/crust at CONIFER BASE = Heterobasidion annosum until proven otherwise. No rhizomorphs separates it from Armillaria. CONIFER host is the first filter — if broadleaf, look elsewhere. Remember: Heterobasidion (three syllables: Het-er-o-bas-id-i-on), annosum (one-N, one-S). Stump treatment knowledge likely to appear in exam context.

clueRoots: Root plate shows brown cubical rot when probed — wood fractures in cube-like blocks, structural roots compromised
clueButt: Large annual bracket at base, velvety surface, yellow-green to rust-brown coloring with distinctive YELLOW-GREEN actively growing outer margin, spongy and soft when fresh
clueLowerStem: Bracket can extend onto lower stem, same yellow-green margin visible, degrades rapidly — fibrous remains from previous years may be visible
clueFoliage: Crown shows progressive thinning, needle drop in conifers, deadwood in lower crown sections — tree declining from root compromise
whyThisFungus: The YELLOW-GREEN growing margin on a large spongy annual bracket at the base of CONIFERS is unique — no other common fungus has this combination. Soft and spongy when fresh (can be pressed with finger). Causes brown cubical rot (wood fractures in cubes — not stringy like white rot). Degrades to fibrous brown remains over winter — old bracket remains are a supporting clue.
keyDifferentiators: MERIPILUS: Rosette of overlapping brackets, bruises brown-black, BROADLEAF not conifer, no yellow-green margin. SPARASSIS: Cauliflower form, no shelf, no yellow-green. HETEROBASIDION: White pore surface, hard woody, no yellow-green margin. UNIQUE TO PHAEOLUS: Yellow-green active margin (diagnostic — no other common fungus), conifer specialist, spongy annual bracket, brown cubical rot, degrades to fibrous rust-brown remains.
clinicalNotes: Host: Conifers (Scots pine, larch, Douglas fir, spruce). Location: Root collar and base. Texture: Soft and spongy when fresh — presses like a sponge. Annual: Appears late summer/autumn, degrades over winter. Remains: Previous year fibrous brown remains often visible near base. Rot type: Brown cubical rot — wood splits along and across grain in cube-like blocks. Color progression: Yellow-green when young → rust-brown when old. Named for mycologist Lewis David de Schweinitz.
examTip: YELLOW-GREEN MARGIN on spongy bracket at CONIFER BASE = Phaeolus schweinitzii. If the bracket is soft and spongy (press it) and growing on a conifer = very likely Phaeolus. Press test useful in field. Remember: Phaeolus (Ph-ae-ol-us), schweinitzii (double-I at end — Schweinitz-ii). Yellow-green is the one unmistakable feature — learn the color.

clueRoots: Root plate shows brown cubical rot — wood fractures along grain, roots structurally compromised in advanced cases
clueButt: Large annual fruiting body at base — PALE CREAM to yellow, multi-lobed wavy fronds forming a cauliflower or brain-like mass, no bracket or shelf form, base attached to roots or root collar
clueLowerStem: Lobed frond mass can reach 50cm diameter, entirely unlike any bracket fungus, soft fleshy texture when fresh
clueFoliage: Crown thinning in Scots pine especially — slow progressive decline as root rot advances over years
whyThisFungus: The cauliflower-like lobed frond structure is COMPLETELY UNIQUE — there is no other common fungus that looks like this at the base of a tree. Cannot be confused with any bracket. Pale cream/yellow multi-lobed mass always at the base of conifers (especially Scots pine). Causes brown cubical rot of roots. Edible when young but never relevant to tree inspection.
keyDifferentiators: ALL BRACKETS: Sparassis has NO bracket or shelf form whatsoever — entirely different morphology. MERIPILUS: Overlapping fan-shaped brackets (not lobed fronds), broadleaf host. PHAEOLUS: Shelf bracket form, yellow-green margin, conifer but bracket shaped. UNIQUE TO SPARASSIS: Cauliflower/brain-like lobed frond mass — morphologically unique, impossible to confuse if seen, conifer specialist (Scots pine primarily), brown cubical rot.
clinicalNotes: Host: Scots pine primarily, occasionally other conifers. Morphology: Unlike any bracket — multi-lobed wavy fronds in a pale cream mass. Size: Large (can exceed 50cm diameter). Annual: Appears late summer/autumn. Texture: Soft fleshy when fresh, becomes tough and dark with age. Rot type: Brown cubical rot of roots and butt. Edibility: Edible when young (culinary value irrelevant to inspection). Name: Crispa = curled/wavy (describes frond form). Risk: Significant — root compromise, windthrow risk.
examTip: CAULIFLOWER or BRAIN-shaped pale cream mass at CONIFER BASE = Sparassis crispa. Only answer possible — morphology is unique. No exam trick, no near-miss — if it looks like a cauliflower at the base of a pine, it is Sparassis. Remember: Sparassis (double-S, one-R), crispa (one-S, one-P — means curled). Easy marks if you learn the shape.

clueRoots: No visible root symptoms — saprophyte on dead wood only
clueButt: Thin bracket clusters on dead wood at base, concentric coloured zones (blue-grey, brown, cream, green-blue) in the same bracket — multicoloured pattern diagnostic
clueLowerStem: Thin brackets on dead stubs at stem base or dead lower stem wood, velvet surface on upper side, white circular pores on underside
clueUpperStem: Thin multicoloured brackets on dead branch stubs higher in crown
clueBranches: Numerous small thin brackets on dead branch stubs throughout crown — tree otherwise healthy or in normal decline
clueFoliage: Crown healthy or normally aged — deadwood expected for species and age. No crown decline caused by Trametes.
whyThisFungus: Thin brackets with MULTIPLE COLOUR ZONES in blue, grey, brown, cream and sometimes green-blue in concentric rings on the SAME bracket — no other common fungus has this multicoloured zoning pattern. Strictly saprophytic — only ever on confirmed dead wood, never on living tissue. Common, widespread, and often alarming to clients who assume it indicates disease. Important for client communication.
keyDifferentiators: GANODERMA: Brown or grey, thick woody brackets, at base, pathogenic. BJERKANDERA: Smoky-grey pores, thin but single grey-brown tone (not multicoloured). FOMES: Grey hoof-shaped, hard woody, not multicoloured. UNIQUE TO TRAMETES: Multicoloured concentric zones (blue, grey, brown, cream — often in same bracket), thin and flexible (not woody), white circular pore surface, STRICTLY saprophytic on dead wood, very common in healthy trees with natural deadwood.
clinicalNotes: Ecology: Strictly saprophytic — colonises dead wood only, never pathogenic. Location: Dead branch stubs, pruning wounds, dead stems. Zones: Multiple colours in concentric rings — same bracket may show blue-grey, brown, cream, green-blue. Texture: Thin, flexible, velvety upper surface. Pores: White, small, circular. Significance: None — indicates deadwood (normal in maturing trees). Client value: Very commonly misidentified as disease — important to communicate it is not a threat. Common name from turkey tail feather resemblance.
examTip: If THIN MULTICOLOURED BRACKETS on dead wood = Trametes versicolor. The multiple colour zones in one bracket are diagnostic — no other common species does this. ALWAYS check it is on DEAD wood — if on living tissue, reconsider. Important for client reassurance: NOT a disease. Remember: Trametes (one-M, one-T), versicolor (versi = varied, color = colour — the name describes it perfectly).

clueRoots: No visible root symptoms — saprophyte and weak pathogen on dead and dying wood
clueButt: Thin to medium brackets on dead or dying wood at base, grey-brown to reddish-brown upper surface with concentric zones, white to pink pore surface underneath
clueLowerStem: Brackets on lower stem, particularly at old wounds — pore surface elongated/maze-like (not circular)
clueUpperStem: Brackets at branch stubs and old wounds higher on stem
clueBranches: Brackets on major branches at attachment points and old pruning wounds
clueFoliage: Crown shows localised dieback above bracket locations on dying branches — not a primary crown pathogen
whyThisFungus: The BLUSHING reaction — pore surface turns PINK to RED when rubbed or bruised — is UNIQUE among common brackets. Test in field: rub the white pore surface firmly with a finger; if it blushes pink, it is Daedaleopsis. Maze-like elongated pores (daedaloid — hence the name) on the underside rather than circular. Willow and alder specialist primarily.
keyDifferentiators: TRAMETES: Multicoloured zones, circular pores, thin, does NOT blush pink. GANODERMA: Hard woody, thick, no blushing. PHELLINUS IGNIARIUS: Grey-black, extremely hard, willow host but no blushing. BJERKANDERA: Smoky-grey pores, thin, no blushing. UNIQUE TO DAEDALEOPSIS: Blushing reaction (pore surface turns pink/red when rubbed — diagnostic test), maze-like elongated pores, willow and alder host, medium thin brackets with zoned brown-red upper surface.
clinicalNotes: Host: Willow (Salix) and alder (Alnus) primarily, occasionally other broadleaves. Location: Wounds, dead branches, dying stems. Blushing test: Rub pore surface firmly — pink/red colour develops within seconds (diagnostic field test). Pores: Elongated maze-like (daedaloid) — between circular and slot-like. Ecology: Weak pathogen and saprophyte — accelerates decline of already stressed trees. Upper surface: Zoned, grey-brown to reddish-brown. Name: Daedaleopsis from Daedalus (labyrinth) — refers to maze-like pore pattern.
examTip: RUB THE PORE SURFACE — if it turns PINK = Daedaleopsis confragosa. This is the diagnostic field test and the most memorable feature. Willow or alder host supports the ID. Remember: Daedaleopsis (Daed-al-e-op-sis — five syllables, double-O before psis), confragosa (one-F, one-G). The blush test is the hook — do it in the field, teach it to clients.
